capital of a political entity
Number of primary health facilities constructed to enhance health services

comment.narrative: Number of primary health facilities constructed to enhance health services

Three clinics in Bong County are equipped with clinical materials for use to aid patients.
Transportation system is provided to help make mobility easier for the Wainsue Clinic PA.

Materials were procured for the clinics in Bong County. These materials have enabled the clinic to provide better services to patients than before.
One motorbike was delivered to the Wainsue Clinic and is currently being used by the Physician Assistant. This has enable to PA to quickly respond to emergency issues in the communities which the clinic service.
Three 3 clinic facilities in Bong County have renewable and sustainable energy (electricity) through the provision and installation of solar power systems.

comment.narrative: -1 senior LNP professionally trained Officer;

Construct 4 magistrates courts construct 2 border posts (Barracks in Nimba and Lofa counties) Train 3 pathologist, Train 108 LNP new recruits, Train 250 BIN new recruits Train 120 BCR new recruits +140 BCR intervention force) -Train 60 college graduates as professional magistrates Train110 existing magistrates in new laws -Enhance prosecution and access to justice for SGBV survivors through support to SGBVCU in Monrovia and Gbarnga hub -Provide support to MOJ-PMU

-250 newly trained BIN officers deployed at border points across the country -108 new recruits trained & awaiting deployment by GOL -137 BCR newly trained officers deployed & have improved manpower capacity at various prisons across the country -3 pathologist successfully completed first year of study and have commenced & received support for year 2 -One magisterial court (Nimba) completed. Montserrado, Lofa & Bong at 75%, 80% & 50% completion rates, respectively -13 months training for 60 professional magistrates commenced March 2016 and ongoing -60 existing magistrates trained in new laws and procedures -Operational & prosecutorial support to SGBV Units ongoing

-Completion of three magisterial court -Construction of one border barrack -Completion of training for 60 Professional magistrates -completion of training for 3 pathologists -Completion of training for existing magistrates

One Magisterial courts (Karnplay, Nimba) completed and handed over 60 magistrates successfully complete 13 months of training and deployed across Liberia Border Barrack construction at 75% completed Construction of two courts (Botota, Bong & Omega, Montserrado) ongoing at 80% & 90% respectively Year two of Pathology training completed

title.narrative: Strengthen Lib Capability to provide climate info & Serv

description.narrative: It will support current climate monitoring and Early Warning Systems in Liberia so as to increase adaptive capacity of local communities and sectors.
Strengthen climate monitoring and Early Warning Systems in Liberia to increase adaptive capacity of local communities and sectors.
capital of a political entity
To strengthen Liberias climaterelated monitoring capabilities early warning systems and available information for responding to climate shocks and planning adaptation to climate change

1 Capacity as per capacity assessment scorecard
2 Domestic finance committed to Meteorology Department Hydrological Services and NDRC to monitor and warn against extreme weather and climate change

comment.narrative:
1 Average capacity scorecard rating of 57 across men and women see Annex 5
2 Annual budget of US 64480 allocated to Meteorology Department annual budget of US 276877 allocated to Hydrological Services and annual budget of US50000 allocated to NDRC

1 Capacity scorecard rating is increased to an average of 134 for both men and women see Annex 5
2 20 increase in annual domestic finance allocated to Meteorology Department Hydrological Services and NDRC to monitor and warn against extreme weather and climate change

Under the reporting period there has been no increase in domestic finance to monitor and warn against climate hazards However we are optimistic that the awareness being generated about the importance of early warnings for the operations of different sectors and when alerts and warnings begin to be issued from the EWS Project and National Meteorological and Hydrological Services NMHS all this will prove the need for public finance and financing from private sources such as the sales of weather products The first year of implementation has been mired by the outbreak of the Ebola Virus Disease which slowed down several aspects of implementation especially fieldbased activities and those involving collaboration with partners and external consultants

description.narrative: Efficient and effective use of tailored climate environmental and socioeconomic data to produce appropriate information which can be communicated to government entities and communities to enable informed decisionmaking

1 Number of communication channels operational to disseminate climaterelated early warnings
2 Percentage of population within the two targeted districts that has access to improved climaterelated flood storm and coastal surge warnings disaggregated by gender

comment.narrative:
1 At present information is relayed to communities mostly via wordofmouth but without the structure of SOPs
2 0 of men
0 of women

1 At least 3 of the following radio television print media newspapers flyers wordofmouth and mobile phone communication channels are operational
2 100 of men
100 of women
These activities were delayed until equipment is procured deployed and climate information is generated to be communicated to target users There is no product to communicate at this stage

description.narrative: Increased awareness in government private sector and local communities of the major risks associated with climate change and use of available information when formulating development policies and strategies
1 Development frameworks that integrate climate information in their formulation

comment.narrative: 1 The Agenda for Transformation 20122017 highlights the need to develop climate change mainstreaming and response strategies but does not emphasize the need for improved information to inform the strategies
1 At least updated Agenda for Transformation to be revised in 2017 to incorporate the availability of climate information into planning for the five year period

The ongoing collaboration with the Ministry of Finance and Development Planning around the EWS Project implementation and other fora organized by other NAPA and National Projects as well as the UNDP will guarantee an entry point for the revision of the AfT when the time comes The MFDP leads the process of developing the Nations development agenda and is a member of the Project Steering Committee The EWS is making inputs into the development of the National Adaptation Plan NAP for Liberia and is poised to integrate climate information into national and sectorial plans

description.narrative: Increased capacity of hydrometeorological services and associated networks to monitor and predict extreme weather climaterelated hazards and climate trends

1 Percentage of national coverage of climate monitoring network fully operational
2 Frequency of data transmission
3 Number of sectorspecific tailored climate information packages produced using improved information

comment.narrative:
1 AWS 0
Hydrometric stations 0
2 At present the 1 AWS transmits data at the synoptic hours of GMT 06h00 09h00 12h00 15h00 18h00 and 00h00 although not consistently
3 At present the only sectorspecific information produced is for the aviation sector

1 AWS 100 at least 9 AWSs
Hyrdometric 100 at least 6 stations
2 18 AWSs and hydrometric stations 11 new AWSs 1 rehabilitated AWS 6 hydrometric stations transmitting continuously
3 Sectorspecific tailored climate information packages produced for three of the following agriculture water aviation fisheriescoastal water users health tourism construction energy and road rail and sea transport

Core activities around this output could not be implemented due to the outbreak of the Ebola Virus Disease EVD and the subsequent delays in the procurement of equipment and services The Government of Liberia requested UNDP to procure equipment along with services like training installation and maintenance Because of the low level of human capital we feel that the procurement of equipment alone cannot guarantee EWS for Liberia and its long term sustainability The long term agreement LTA to be issued by CIRDA is the best option for the country The EVD also hampered other capacity building activities as experts could not come into the country and staff could not be accepted in several countries for training In 2014 negotiations with the World Meteorological Organization Training Institutions in Nigeria and Kenya collapsed because of the EVD but responses from both countries are advanced and students will be sent over by 4th quarter Probably the most substantive deliverable for the year besides training will be the renovation of the building to be used as the National Meteorological Center NMC within the premises of the Roberts International Airport This project is to begin during the 4th quarter

description.narrative: The Liberia Decentralization Support Program (LDSP), presents the strategy, results framework and operational modalities for a five-year program of support to the decentralization of political, administrative, and fiscal governance in Liberia.

description.narrative:
% of women and men aware of basic decentralization goals and decentralization related activities undertaken in their county/locality Draft Communication Strategy validated # of students sensitized on decentralization # of CSOs participating in decentralization activities # of information centers established
# of county, city and district administrations having access to computers, email and internet facilities.
# of administrative offices made functional in the counties, cities and districts aligned with cost effective plan

comment.narrative:
Recent survey (2013) results show that more than 80% of the general population have limited or no knowledge on decentralization and the benefit of share governance
Local government offices in the 15 counties do not have office space and supporting infrastructure to accommodate the MACs.
4 additional County Service Centers (CSCs) opened by December 2016. Participatory decentralization planning and budgeting processes organized in at least 2 counties.

4 County Service Centers (CSCs) were operational in 2016 providing much needed decentralized services to people in Bong, Nimba, Grand Bassa and Margibi Counties. In 2016, the Centers responded to 22,363 persons thereby generating over 12 million Liberian Dollars (about 200,000 USD).

All 15 County Service Centers (CSCs) open.
Civil society organizations disseminate information on the importance and use of the County Service Centers.

15 County Service Centers (CSCs) are operational, bringing services to people across the country. 14 services including birth certificates, driver licenses, western & traditional marriage certificates and business registrations are issued at the centers. This is important as it has generated over half a million US Dollars in revenue while creating easy access to basic social services to the populace.
To further enhance use of the CSCs, 11 CSOs had thecapacities strengthen which have led to a greater awareness of the CSCs within many rural locales.

description.narrative: • Number of functioning CRC focal points • Number of proposals prepared and submitted Number Of documents reviewed according to plan/ # of persons trained ( gender dissagregated) • There are many policy documents available • The 1986 constitution is available • LRC/GC are mandated to provide technical support by CRC TOR • LRC/GC operational • LRC and GC have limited capacity

comment.narrative: • CRC was established on 30th August 2012 with limited mandate • The CRC has no rented office. • 6 full time CRC members appointed by November 2012 • CRC is in process of preparing action Plan • There are many policy documents available • The 1986 constitution is available • LRC/GC are mandated to provide technical support by CRC TOR • LRC/GC operational • LRC and GC have limited capacity
support civic and legislative advocacy in at least 10 counties through CSOs

7 CSOs have conducted close to 80 activities including sensitization and legislative town hall meetings, social mobilization and community mappings, palava-huts, workshops and dialogues, production of radio dramas, jingles and talk shows, focus groups, production of flyers, training and dialogues in about 34 locations in 7 Counties, to help deepen citizens’ engagement in the constitutional review process.

•Provide grants to civil society organizations and media organizations, in particular to women’s and minority groups •Support CSOs and media to conduct civic education on and disseminate draft proposals •Institutional support to Law Reform Commission to provide support to legislature in formulating the preparation of concrete and well structure propositions •Archiving of documents related to the CRC

Law reform commission: special sessions held with senate & house joint committees to harmonize proposals & secure a referendum bill; archived all materials related to constitution review project csos: joint meetings with senators, representatives & commissioners from LRC one on one meetings with influential representatives & senators, text messages ,banners, posters, & town hall meetings.

• Organize a two day acquaintance meeting for members of the 54th Legislature (House of Reps) • Hold separate meetings with the leadership of both Houses • Electronic media engagement through the production and airing of jingles • Provide grants to CSOs and media to engage Legislatures and their constituents

title.narrative: Strengthen Transparency, Accountability, Oversight and P

description.narrative: STAOP aims to support strengthening governance and promoting transparency and accountability.

title.narrative: Outcome 30 -National reconciliation and social cohesion fostered within an enabling constitutional and legal environment supported by a strengthened and accountable justice and security institutions at national and local level.

description.narrative: The project aims to strengthen corruption prevention, transparency and accountability and provide support to both state institutions and civil society organizations to increase transparency and accountability in governance processes
capital of a political entity
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

Indicators: -Increased levels of dialogue at the national and local level on strategies to improve transparency and accountability -No. of initiatives between oversight institutions and line ministries to improve transparency and accountability
Indicators: -Procedural and performance standards established , based on the findings of risk assessments and audits -Increased efficiency in financial management and service delivery -Increased levels of access to information to official data
Indicators •Procedural and performance standards established , based on the findings of audits -Improved capacity to manage development funds and deliver services
Indicator: -Increased access to information on concessions and revenues generated -No. of Public hearing of LEITI reports in the catchment area of concessionaries institutionalized -Extent of Civil society (including women and youth organizations) and media engagement in providing information on all aspects of the industry in an easily-accessible format to the public
Indicator: -Increased knowledge of UNCAC and the UNCAC self-assessment process -Increased coordination and networking between oversight institutions, ministries and agencies, civil society and media around UNCAC -Measures taken to address gaps identified through the self-assessment processes
Indicators: -Increased capacity of LACC -Level of investigative independence of LACC (both proactive and reactive detection -Increased public perception of LACC’s capability to address corruption
Indicators: -Existence of participatory initiatives (involving women and youth) to promote transparency and accountability at national and local level, particularly in service delivery -Increased levels of access to information -Increased coverage of media on transparency and accountability -Increased coverage of media on transparency and accountability with women and youth specific messages

comment.narrative:
Baseline: high awareness of corruption issues but limited dialogue and engagement on prevention, transparency and accountability
Baseline: -varying levels of prevention measures adopted in line ministries -limited data on efficiency in service delivery and financial management in line ministries and agencies, and on service delivery -Corruption risk in the Education sector assessed.
Baseline: •lack of internal control in county administration (based on 2010 audit report) •limited capacity to manage development funds and deliver services
Baseline: -Lack of consolidated information on concessions awarded, revenues generated and invested and environmental and social impact of extractive industry and natural resource sector - limited compliance of concessionaries to requirements of EITI reporting - limited knowledge and confidence of general public in the LEITI process
Baseline: -Limited awareness of UNCAC and opportunities presented by UNCAC to support anti-corruption reforms
Baseline: -Limited capacity of LACC to investigate and prosecute corruption cases. -Investigation rates of LACC caseload is only nine percent
Baseline: -Emerging capacity of Civil society and community based organizations to monitor service delivery -Lack of information on services provided at the local level - Limited capacity of CSOs and media to monitor service delivery

1. Refurbish and erect three (3) bill boards to create awareness on procurement reforms 2. 10 media Houses report on International Anti-Corruption Day (IACD) 3. Train at least fifteen (15) internal auditors in internal auditing with 30% constituting females staff 4. Establish Five (5) Student Integrity Clubs in five (5) assessed public high schools in Montserrado County 5. Erect Five (5) information bulletin boards in five (5) assessed public high schools in Montserrado 6. Train fifteen (15) LACC staff (14 males and 1 female) in information/data collection and analysis 7. Provide external training to two (2) LACC prosecutors in the handling of corruption cases, including in case selection, and forensic financial investigation 8. Establish a digitized electronic database for the National Civil Society Council of Liberia

Three (3) bill boards refurbished and erected at strategic locations in Montserrado to create awareness on procurement reforms; Over 10 media Houses reported on events of the International Anti-Corruption Day (IACD), held in Gbarnga City, Bong County, Liberia; at least fifteen (15) internal auditors were trained in internal auditing with 30% constituting females staff; Five (5) Student Integrity Clubs were established in five (5) assessed public high schools in Montserrado County while five (5) information bulletin boards were also erected in the five (5) assessed public high schools in Montserrado county; fifteen (15) LACC staff (14 males and 1 female) were trained in information/data collection and analysis and this has bolstered the capacity of the LACC in handling investigative cases; Four (4) staff, including three staff from LACC (one female and 2 males) and one staff from Ministry of Justice were trained at the Egerton University in Kenya in forensic science and investigation, especially in the handling of corruption cases, including in case selection, and forensic financial investigation; and established a digitized electronic database for the National Civil Society Council of Liberia.

Increase by 25% sui-moto prosecutions; increases by 25% investigations on Corruption; Conduct Capacity assessment; develop a capacity development plan specifically for increasing prosecutorial capacity and for understanding the effectiveness of Asset Disclosure system; erect 10 billboards; hold 36 radio talk shows on procurement processes; produce 5 jingles procurement processes of the PPCC; air 4,368 spots of jingles in Monrovia; air 2,496 spots of jingles in the counties; increase internet bandwidth to 10 MBps; install robust firewall; establish external access to PPCC document management system; produce ID cards and call cards for all of PPCC staff; hold at least 10 open expenditure initiative events; organize at least 2 events to create awareness on illicit financial flows in Liberia; organize one major event to talk about integrity in the civil service.

Purchased one vehicle; hired one experienced lawyer to support the LACC in its pursuit to prosecute those charged with corruption; hired and trained five (5) investigators; provided external training in forensic investigations to three (3) LACC staff; established a state-of-the-art cybercrime lab with surveillance equipment; setting up and equipping of investigative pool room with furniture and ICT equipment; and hiring of one data clerk and setting up of data clerk office with furniture and ICT equipment; supported the erection of three giant-sized billboards in locations in Montserrado and Margibi counties; supported purchase of one ID card and business card machine; procured a 10MBps internet bandwidth to increase the internet bandwidth of PPCC; procured firewall to provide internet security for PPCC e-procurement portal; and supported to development and airing of radio jingles as well as hosting of radio talk shows on E-tendering and procurement compliance processes; Through the use of CSOs the following activities were supported: Provided support to the four CSOs (FIND, IREDD, LMDI and DEN-L) to carryout various forms of engagements including debates among students, training of CBOs to engage community members, radio talk shows, jingles and dramas to increase the level of awareness surrounding accountability, transparency, integrity and corruption issues in Liberia.

Indicator 1.2: # of Finance staff enrolled for accounting certification with 25% women representation Indicator 1.3: # of MACs Procurement staff undertake hands-on training and CIPS Level 2 certification with 25% women representation Indicator 1.4: Online M&E national database portal # of M&E plans # of M&E reports uploaded on database # of sector projects Indicator: 1.5: # of M&E manuals printed and distributed Indicator 1.6: Curriculum on short-term National Implementation (NIM) training developed

Output 4: Indicator 4.1: # of staff with technical skills in respective functional area Indictor4.2: # of LRA Medium Term (3-5 years) IT Strategy developed and being adhere to # of servers for Data Center being constructed at LRA HQ # of industrial copiers to effectuate enhanced IT service delivery # of vehicle to facilitate mobility of IT team between HQ, sector ministries and Tax and Customs Business Offices

comment.narrative:
Output 1: Baseline: (2014) Gaps identified in micro-assessment for program implementation, financial reporting and procurement capacities of 40 MAC
Baseline: (2014) 36 MACs Finance Staff started training on ATSWA/CPA at LIPA coordinated by LICPA

1st Quarter 2016 National Launch of the SDGs Her Excellency President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf, on January 26, 2017, launched the new development global framework, Agenda 2030, which replaces the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs, 2000-2015). President Sirleaf, as co-Chair of the United High Level Panel of Eminent Persons on the Post-2015 and Chair of the African Union High Level Committee of Heads of State and Government on the Post-2015.
The three-day event brought together members of the Government, Civil Society Organizations, the Private Sector, Academia, Youth and Women Organizations and the Media. The United Nations Sustainable Development Solutions Network (UN-SDSN) of Columbia University, New York and the United Nations System in Liberia collaborated with the organizers in the planning and execution of the program.
The outcome of the National Launch at the end of the two days of stakeholders’ deliberations focused on ways to create synergy and align Liberia’s development key priorities with the various global development agendas to ensure effective implementation of the SDGs. Amongst Liberia’s key priorities from the SDGs as outlined by Minister Amara Konneh, are SDG 3 (Health); SDG 4 (Education); SDG 5 (Gender Equality); SDG 6 (Clean water and sanitation); SDG 9 (Infrastructure); SDG 16 (Peace society); and SDG 17 (Global Partnership). Minister Konneh also announced the formation of an Inter-Ministerial SDGs Taskforce led by the Ministry of Finance and Development Planning.
Effective Coordination of GOL/UNDP programme The MFDP effectively managed the signing of the 2016 annual work plans were with a total of eight 10) projects’/programs’ Annual Work Plans have been signed out of 14 with four projects/programs outstanding awaiting their respective project board meetings. This has been the best ever coordination process conducting board meeting by clustering all programmes/projects under respective CPD Outcome/Pillar level which was effectively managed t

• A total of 227 procurement practitioners have benefited from CIPS levels 2,3 and 4 trainings comprising of 151 male and 76 female resulting to 67% and 33% respectively from both national and subnational with over 70 institutions represented. The knowledge they have acquired will improve their skills in public procurement to internationally recommended standards; contribute to efficiency; professionalize the procurement profession in Liberia and address the human resource constraints faced by many government institutions in the administration of procurement. Youtube videos, Newspaper articles, PPCC Workshop Reports, www.ppcc.gov.lr; https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=K1tOd2NG8p0&feature=youtu.be https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nS5vq_hrazw&feature=youtu.be; http://allafrica.com/stories/201711140786.html
• 7,000 copies of national citizen guide published to inform Liberian citizens on national allocation. www.mfdp.gov.lr
• Enterprise Risk Management and Domestic Revenue Mobilization (DRM) strategy to boast national tax revenue collection. www.lra.gov.lr
• National Document on Baseline Indicators for Key Sector Plans, AfT-II, SDGs G7+ and Agenda 2063. Provides basis for measuring development interventions of the next medium term plan; serve as tool for M&E purposes and policy making. www.mfdp.gov.lr
• SDGs, Africa 2063 Agenda awareness conducted in 12 counties with local leaders, religious leaders, chiefs, CSOs women, youths, persons living with disabilities, private sector, media and students panel debates held. Beneficiaries included Liberia Western Region - 445 participants (272 M & 173 F); Central Region – 565 (343 M & 222 F); South East – 525 (262 M & 263 F). Video Address by Minister MFDP; http://allafrica.com/stories/201708250595.html; www.lra.gov.lr
